> I've a question regarding adaptive and self-adaptive schemes and
> Jeff's paper: I understand that such approach could make things worse
> if the search get stuck in a local minima; but what could we expect if
> we combine them with a (hopefully good) diversity preservation
> nechanism (e.g. the one in NEAT)?
> 
> My intuition is that the diversity should work against the "trap" of
> the local minima in this case.

Hello Jean-Baptiste-

Thanks for your interest in the work. I think your question is an
interesting one, but I do not think it affords an easy general answer. My
guess is that the result of combining the evolution of mutation rates with
diversity preservation would depend highly on the particulars of the
implementation. 

Imagine a population on a local peak. My work shows that there is a strong
pressure to lower the mutation rate in the absence of a diversity preserving
mechanism.  A diversity mechanism would effectively give a fitness boost for
organisms that were different from the current population, and the only way
to obtain that is to have a higher mutation rate. So, there would be a short
term increase in the mutation rate *if* the fitness boost from the diversity
promotion mechanism was stronger than the pressure to lower rates.

But even if the diversity pressure is strong enough to overcome the pressure
to reduce mutation rates, what happens soon thereafter? Imagine that
organisms find a couple other local peaks, say one peak per species. Now the
diversity preservation mechanism will become watered down, since there is a
healthy amount of diversity, but the mutation rate pressure will floor the
rate and the population will become permanently trapped on those various
local peaks. Again, a different diversity mechanism might overcome this
problem...but you can see that it will require a lot of tweaking because you
have these opposing forces.

But, more importantly, what good is the evolution of the mutation rate doing
for you? I don't see it helping much, since it is only trying to run up the
side of the current fitness hill and then zero out the rate. I don't know
that we want a pressure like that in the mix if our goal is long-term
adaptation. 

I should note that I began this research with a similar goal: using
something from evolution to help evolution evolve good mutation rates. In my
case, I thought that group selection would cause the evolution of mutation
rates that were good for the group's long-term goals at the expense of the
individual member's short-term goals. I was able to show, as theory
predicts, that group selection can bring about the evolution of altruism.
But it turned out that no matter how hard I tried I could never overcome the
downward pressure on mutation rates. It is very strong. That is why my
instincts tell me that it would be hard to get the diversity mechanism to
overcome this downward pressure in an elegant and productive way.

What do you think?

In any case, it is worth a shot if you want to test it out. If you do, I
would be very interested in the results.

Cheers, Jeff
